baseline: The Hindu calendar, Panchanga (Sanskrit: पञ्चाङ्ग) or Panjika is one of various lunisolar calendars that are traditionally used in the Indian subcontinent and Southeast Asia, with further regional variations for social and Hindu religious purposes.

prompts: Of the various regional calendars , the most studied and known Hindu calendars are
baseline: Of the various regional calendars, the most studied and known Hindu calendars are the Shalivahana Shaka (Based on the King Shalivahana, also the Indian national calendar) found in the Deccan region of Southern India and the Vikram Samvat (Bikrami) found in Nepal and the North and Central regions of India – both of which emphasise the lunar cycle.

prompts: In regions such as Tamil Nadu and Kerala , the solar cycle is emphasised and this is
baseline: In regions such as Tamil Nadu and Kerala, the solar cycle is emphasised and this is called the Tamil calendar (though Tamil calendar uses month names like in Hindu Calendar) and Malayalam calendar and these have origins in the second half of the 1st millennium CE.

prompts: A Hindu calendar is sometimes referred to as Panchangam ( पञ्चाङ्गम् ) , which is also known as Panjika in
baseline: A Hindu calendar is sometimes referred to as Panchangam (पञ्चाङ्गम्), which is also known as Panjika in Eastern India.

prompts: The ancient Hindu calendar conceptual design is also found in the Hebrew
baseline: The ancient Hindu calendar conceptual design is also found in the Hebrew calendar, the Chinese calendar, and the Babylonian calendar, but different from the Gregorian calendar.

prompts: Unlike the Gregorian calendar which adds additional days to the month to adjust for the mismatch
baseline: Unlike the Gregorian calendar which adds additional days to the month to adjust for the mismatch between twelve lunar cycles (354 lunar days) and nearly 365 solar days, the Hindu calendar maintains the integrity of the lunar month, but inserts an extra full month, once every 32–33 months, to ensure that the festivals and crop-related rituals fall in the appropriate season.

prompts: The Hindu calendars have been in use in the Indian subcontinent since Vedic times , and remain in use by
baseline: The Hindu calendars have been in use in the Indian subcontinent since Vedic times, and remain in use by the Hindus all over the world, particularly to set Hindu festival dates.

prompts: The Buddhist calendar and the traditional lunisolar calendars of Cambodia , Laos , Myanmar , Sri Lanka and Thailand are also based on an older
baseline: The Buddhist calendar and the traditional lunisolar calendars of Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, Sri Lanka and Thailand are also based on an older version of the Hindu calendar.

prompts: Similarly , the ancient Jain traditions have followed the same lunisolar
baseline: Similarly, the ancient Jain traditions have followed the same lunisolar system as the Hindu calendar for festivals, texts and inscriptions.

prompts: The Hindu calendar is also important to
baseline: The Hindu calendar is also important to the practice of Hindu astrology and zodiac system.

prompts: In whatever way a Hindu defines the goal of life , there are several methods (
baseline: In whatever way a Hindu defines the goal of life, there are several methods (yogas) that sages have taught for reaching that goal.

prompts: Yoga is a Hindu discipline which trains the body ,
baseline: Yoga is a Hindu discipline which trains the body, mind, and consciousness for health, tranquility, and spiritual insight.

prompts: The cow in Hindu society is traditionally identified as a caretaker
baseline: The cow in Hindu society is traditionally identified as a caretaker and a maternal figure, and Hindu society honours the cow as a symbol of unselfish giving, selfless sacrifice, gentleness and tolerance.

prompts: There are many Hindu groups that have continued to abide by
baseline: There are many Hindu groups that have continued to abide by a strict vegetarian diet in modern times.

prompts: Food affects body , mind
baseline: Food affects body, mind and spirit in Hindu beliefs.

prompts: Hindu texts such as Śāṇḍilya Upanishad and Svātmārāma recommend Mitahara ( eating
baseline: Hindu texts such as Śāṇḍilya Upanishad and Svātmārāma recommend Mitahara (eating in moderation) as one of the Yamas (virtuous Self restraints).

prompts: A Hindu temple is a house of
baseline: A Hindu temple is a house of god(s).

prompts: A temple incorporates all elements of Hindu cosmology , the highest spire or dome representing Mount Meru
baseline: A temple incorporates all elements of Hindu cosmology, the highest spire or dome representing Mount Meru – reminder of the abode of Brahma and the center of spiritual universe, the carvings and iconography symbolically presenting dharma, kama, artha, moksha and karma.

prompts: Hindu temples are spiritual destinations for
baseline: Hindu temples are spiritual destinations for many Hindus (not all), as well as landmarks for arts, annual festivals, rite of passage rituals, and community celebrations.

prompts: Hindu temples come in many styles , diverse locations , deploy different construction methods
baseline: Hindu temples come in many styles, diverse locations, deploy different construction methods and are adapted to different deities and regional beliefs.

prompts: Two major styles of Hindu temples include the Gopuram style
baseline: Two major styles of Hindu temples include the Gopuram style found in south India, and Nagara style found in north India.

prompts: Yet , despite their differences , almost all Hindu temples share certain common architectural
baseline: Yet, despite their differences, almost all Hindu temples share certain common architectural principles, core ideas, symbolism and themes.

prompts: Kauai Hindu monastery in Kauai Island in Hawaii is the only Hindu
baseline: Kauai Hindu monastery in Kauai Island in Hawaii is the only Hindu Monastery in the North American continent.

prompts: Traditionally the life of a Hindu is divided into four Āśramas
baseline: Traditionally the life of a Hindu is divided into four Āśramas (phases or life stages; another meaning includes monastery).

prompts: Grihastha stage starts with Hindu wedding , and has been considered the most important
baseline: Grihastha stage starts with Hindu wedding, and has been considered the most important of all stages in sociological context, as Hindus in this stage not only pursued a virtuous life, they produced food and wealth that sustained people in other stages of life, as well as the offsprings that continued mankind.

prompts: Combined with four proper goals of human life ( Purusartha ) , the Ashramas system traditionally aimed at
baseline: Combined with four proper goals of human life (Purusartha), the Ashramas system traditionally aimed at providing a Hindu with fulfilling life and spiritual liberation.

prompts: A Hindu monk is called a Sanyāsī ,
baseline: A Hindu monk is called a Sanyāsī, Sādhu, or Swāmi.

prompts: Renunciates receive high respect in Hindu society because of their simple ahiṃsā - driven lifestyle and dedication
baseline: Renunciates receive high respect in Hindu society because of their simple ahiṃsā-driven lifestyle and dedication to spiritual liberation (moksha) – believed to be the ultimate goal of life in Hinduism.

prompts: The subsequent period , between 800 BCE and 200 BCE , is " a turning
baseline: The subsequent period, between 800 BCE and 200 BCE, is "a turning point between the Vedic religion and Hindu religions", and a formative period for Hinduism, Jainism and Buddhism.

prompts: In this period the six branches of Hindu philosophy evolved , namely Samkhya
baseline: In this period the six branches of Hindu philosophy evolved, namely Samkhya, Yoga, Nyaya, Vaisheshika, Mīmāṃsā, and Vedanta.

prompts: The Hindu Shore Temple at Mahabalipuram was built by Narasimhavarman II
baseline: The Hindu Shore Temple at Mahabalipuram was built by Narasimhavarman II.

prompts: Hinduism under both Hindu and Islamic rulers from c.   1250–1750   CE , saw the increasing prominence
baseline: Hinduism under both Hindu and Islamic rulers from c. 1250–1750 CE, saw the increasing prominence of the Bhakti movement, which remains influential today.

prompts: The colonial period saw the emergence of various Hindu reform movements partly inspired by western movements
baseline: The colonial period saw the emergence of various Hindu reform movements partly inspired by western movements, such as Unitarianism and Theosophy.

prompts: The Partition of India in 1947 was along religious lines
baseline: The Partition of India in 1947 was along religious lines, with the Republic of India emerging with a Hindu majority.

prompts: During the 20th century , due to the Indian diaspora , Hindu minorities have formed in all continents
baseline: During the 20th century, due to the Indian diaspora, Hindu minorities have formed in all continents, with the largest communities in absolute numbers in the United States, and the United Kingdom.

prompts: Religious leaders of some Hindu reform movements such as the Arya Samaj launched Shuddhi movement to
baseline: Religious leaders of some Hindu reform movements such as the Arya Samaj launched Shuddhi movement to proselytise and reconvert Muslims and Christians back to Hinduism, while those such as the Brahmo Samaj suggested Hinduism to be a non-missionary religion.

prompts: There have also been an increase of
baseline: There have also been an increase of Hindu identity in politics, mostly in India, Nepal and Bangladesh in the form of Hindutva.

prompts: The revivalist movement was mainly started and encouraged by many organisations
baseline: The revivalist movement was mainly started and encouraged by many organisations like RSS, BJP and other organisations of Sangh Parivar in India, while there are also many Hindu nationalist parties and organisations such as Shivsena Nepal and RPP in Nepal, HINDRAF in Malaysia, etc.

prompts: India contains 94 % of
baseline: India contains 94% of the global Hindu population.

prompts: The word Hindū is an exonym , and is derived from the Sanskrit
baseline: The word Hindū is an exonym, and is derived from the Sanskrit root Sindhu, believed to be the name of the Indus River in the northwestern part of the Indian subcontinent.

prompts: This Arabic term was itself taken from the pre
baseline: This Arabic term was itself taken from the pre-Islamic Persian term Hindū.

prompts: The major kinds , according to McDaniel are Folk Hinduism ,
baseline: The major kinds, according to McDaniel are Folk Hinduism, based on local traditions and cults of local deities and is the oldest, non-literate system; Vedic Hinduism based on the earliest layers of the Vedas, traceable to the 2nd millennium BCE; Vedantic Hinduism based on the philosophy of the Upanishads, including Advaita Vedanta, emphasising knowledge and wisdom; Yogic Hinduism, following the text of Yoga Sutras of Patanjali emphasising introspective awareness; Dharmic Hinduism or "daily morality", which McDaniel states is stereotyped in some books as the "only form of Hindu religion with a belief in karma, cows and caste"; and bhakti or devotional Hinduism, where intense emotions are elaborately incorporated in the pursuit of the spiritual.

prompts: To many Hindus , Hinduism is a tradition that can be traced at least to
baseline: To many Hindus, Hinduism is a tradition that can be traced at least to the ancient Vedic era.

prompts: Whatever the case , many Hindu religious sources see persons or groups
baseline: Whatever the case, many Hindu religious sources see persons or groups which they consider as non-Vedic (and which reject Vedic varṇāśrama – 'caste and life stage' orthodoxy) as being heretics (pāṣaṇḍa/pākhaṇḍa).

prompts: However , adds Sanderson , this Shaiva ascetic tradition viewed themselves as being
baseline: However, adds Sanderson, this Shaiva ascetic tradition viewed themselves as being genuinely true to the Vedic tradition and "held unanimously that the Śruti and Smṛti of Brahmanism are universally and uniquely valid in their own sphere,  and that as such they  are man's sole means of valid knowledge ".

prompts: The Vaidika dharma or " Vedic way of life " , states Lipner , does not mean " Hinduism is
baseline: The Vaidika dharma or "Vedic way of life", states Lipner, does not mean "Hinduism is necessarily religious" or that Hindus have a universally accepted "conventional or institutional meaning" for that term.

prompts: Brahmins played an essential role in the development of the post - Vedic Hindu synthesis , disseminating Vedic culture to
baseline: Brahmins played an essential role in the development of the post-Vedic Hindu synthesis, disseminating Vedic culture to local communities, and integrating local religiosity into the trans-regional Brahmanic culture.

prompts: In the post - Gupta period Vedanta developed in southern India
baseline: In the post-Gupta period Vedanta developed in southern India, where orthodox Brahmanic culture and the Hindu culture were preserved, building on ancient Vedic traditions while "accommoda the multiple demands of Hinduism."

prompts: Lorenzen traces the emergence of a " family resemblance " , and what he calls as " beginnings
baseline: Lorenzen traces the emergence of a "family resemblance", and what he calls as "beginnings of medieval and modern Hinduism" taking shape, at c. 300–600 CE, with the development of the early Puranas, and continuities with the earlier Vedic religion.

prompts: Beginning in the 19th century , Indian modernists re - asserted Hinduism
baseline: Beginning in the 19th century, Indian modernists re-asserted Hinduism as a major asset of Indian civilisation, meanwhile "purifying" Hinduism from its Tantric elements and elevating the Vedic elements.

prompts: Of the Shrutis ( Vedic corpus ) , the Upanishads alone are widely influential among
baseline: Of the Shrutis (Vedic corpus), the Upanishads alone are widely influential among Hindus, considered scriptures par excellence of Hinduism, and their central ideas have continued to influence its thoughts and traditions.

prompts: Since the 19th - century Indian modernists have re - asserted the
baseline: Since the 19th-century Indian modernists have re-asserted the 'Aryan origins' of Hinduism, "purifying" Hinduism from its Tantric elements and elevating the Vedic elements.

prompts: Karma translates literally as action , work , or deed , and also
baseline: Karma translates literally as action, work, or deed, and also refers to a Vedic theory of "moral law of cause and effect".

prompts: The later Vedic texts such as the Aranyakas and the Upanisads show a different soteriology
baseline: The later Vedic texts such as the Aranyakas and the Upanisads show a different soteriology based on reincarnation, they show little concern with ancestor rites, and they begin to philosophically interpret the earlier rituals.

prompts: The idea of reincarnation and karma have roots in the
baseline: The idea of reincarnation and karma have roots in the Upanishads of the late Vedic period, predating the Buddha and the Mahavira.

prompts: The " One Truth " of Vedic literature , in modern era scholarship , has been interpreted as monotheism ,
baseline: The "One Truth" of Vedic literature, in modern era scholarship, has been interpreted as monotheism, monism, as well as a deified Hidden Principles behind the great happenings and processes of nature.

prompts: This perception of divinity manifested in all things , as Buttimer and Wallin view it , makes
baseline: This perception of divinity manifested in all things, as Buttimer and Wallin view it, makes the Vedic foundations of Hinduism quite distinct from animism, in which all things are themselves divine.

prompts: The Vedic view does not perceive this competition , equality of man to nature , or multiplicity so much as an overwhelming and interconnecting single divinity that
baseline: The Vedic view does not perceive this competition, equality of man to nature, or multiplicity so much as an overwhelming and interconnecting single divinity that unifies everyone and everything.

prompts: The word avatar does not appear in the Vedic literature ;   It appears in verb forms
baseline: The word avatar does not appear in the Vedic literature;  It appears in verb forms in post-Vedic literature, and as a noun particularly in the Puranic literature after the 6th century CE.

prompts: A typical Hindu wedding is solemnised before Vedic fire
baseline: A typical Hindu wedding is solemnised before Vedic fire ritual (shown).

prompts: Vedic rituals of fire - oblation ( yajna ) and chanting of Vedic hymns
baseline: Vedic rituals of fire-oblation (yajna) and chanting of Vedic hymns are observed on special occasions, such as a Hindu wedding.

prompts: Other major life - stage events , such as rituals after death , include the yajña and
baseline: Other major life-stage events, such as rituals after death, include the yajña and chanting of Vedic mantras.

prompts: The words of the mantras are " themselves sacred , " and " do not constitute linguistic utterances .
baseline: The words of the mantras are "themselves sacred," and "do not constitute linguistic utterances." Instead, as Klostermaier notes, in their application in Vedic rituals they become magical sounds, "means to an end." In the Brahmanical perspective, the sounds have their own meaning, mantras are considered "primordial rhythms of creation", preceding the forms to which they refer.

prompts: The Hindu calendars have been in use in the Indian subcontinent since Vedic times , and remain in use by
baseline: The Hindu calendars have been in use in the Indian subcontinent since Vedic times, and remain in use by the Hindus all over the world, particularly to set Hindu festival dates.

prompts: Early Buddhist communities of India adopted the ancient Vedic
baseline: Early Buddhist communities of India adopted the ancient Vedic calendar, later Vikrami calendar and then local Buddhist calendars.

prompts: They are the Brahmins :
baseline: They are the Brahmins: Vedic teachers and priests; the Kshatriyas: warriors and kings; the Vaishyas: farmers and merchants; and the Shudras: servants and labourers.

prompts: While the traditional Itihasa - Purana   and the Epic - Puranic chronology derived from it present
baseline: While the traditional Itihasa-Purana  and the Epic-Puranic chronology derived from it present Hinduism as a tradition existing for thousands of years, scholars regard Hinduism as a synthesis of various Indian cultures and traditions, with diverse roots and no single founder, which emerged after the Vedic period, between c. 500–200 BCE and c. 300 CE.

prompts: The first period is the pre - Vedic period , which includes the Indus Valley
baseline: The first period is the pre-Vedic period, which includes the Indus Valley Civilization and local pre-historic religions, ending at about 1750 BCE.

prompts: This period was followed in northern India by the Vedic period , which saw the introduction of
baseline: This period was followed in northern India by the Vedic period, which saw the introduction of the historical Vedic religion with the Indo-Aryan migrations, starting somewhere between 1900 BCE to 1400 BCE.

prompts: The subsequent period , between 800 BCE and 200 BCE , is " a turning
baseline: The subsequent period, between 800 BCE and 200 BCE, is "a turning point between the Vedic religion and Hindu religions", and a formative period for Hinduism, Jainism and Buddhism.

prompts: The word Hindu is an exonym , and while Hinduism has been called the oldest religion
baseline: The word Hindu is an exonym, and while Hinduism has been called the oldest religion in the world, it has also been described as sanātana dharma (Sanskrit: सनातन धर्म, lit. ''the eternal dharma''), a modern usage, based on the belief that its origins lie beyond human history, as revealed in the Hindu texts.

prompts: The word Hindū is an exonym , and is derived from the Sanskrit
baseline: The word Hindū is an exonym, and is derived from the Sanskrit root Sindhu, believed to be the name of the Indus River in the northwestern part of the Indian subcontinent.

prompts: According to Gavin Flood , " The actual term Hindu first occurs as a Persian
baseline: According to Gavin Flood, "The actual term Hindu first occurs as a Persian geographical term for the people who lived beyond the river Indus (Sanskrit: Sindhu)", more specifically in the 6th-century BCE inscription of Darius I (550–486 BCE).

prompts: The word dharma is used here to mean religion similar to
baseline: The word dharma is used here to mean religion similar to modern Indo-Aryan languages, rather than with its original Sanskrit meaning.

prompts: The word ' Vaidika ' in Sanskrit means ' derived from
baseline: The word 'Vaidika' in Sanskrit means 'derived from or conformable to the Veda' or 'relating to the Veda'.

prompts: According to Alexis Sanderson , the early Sanskrit texts differentiate between Vaidika ,
baseline: According to Alexis Sanderson, the early Sanskrit texts differentiate between Vaidika, Vaishnava, Shaiva, Shakta, Saura, Buddhist and Jaina traditions.

prompts: According to the Indologist Alexis Sanderson , before Islam arrived in India ,
baseline: According to the Indologist Alexis Sanderson, before Islam arrived in India, the "Sanskrit sources differentiated Vaidika, Vaiṣṇava, Śaiva, Śākta, Saura, Buddhist, and Jaina traditions, but they had no name that denotes the first five of these as a collective entity over and against Buddhism and Jainism".

prompts: Kāma ( Sanskrit , Pali : काम ) means desire , wish
baseline: Kāma (Sanskrit, Pali: काम) means desire, wish, passion, longing, and pleasure of the senses, the aesthetic enjoyment of life, affection and love, with or without sexual connotations.

prompts: Moksha ( Sanskrit : मोक्ष , romanized :   mokṣa ) or mukti ( Sanskrit : मुक्ति ) is the ultimate ,
baseline: Moksha (Sanskrit: मोक्ष, romanized: mokṣa) or mukti (Sanskrit: मुक्ति) is the ultimate, most important goal in Hinduism.

prompts: Hindu festivals ( Sanskrit : Utsava ; literally : " to lift higher " ) are ceremonies that weave
baseline: Hindu festivals (Sanskrit: Utsava; literally: "to lift higher") are ceremonies that weave individual and social life to dharma.

prompts: The architectural guidelines survive in Sanskrit manuscripts
baseline: The architectural guidelines survive in Sanskrit manuscripts and in some cases also in other regional languages.

prompts: The Hindu calendar , Panchanga ( Sanskrit : पञ्चाङ्ग ) or Panjika is one of various
baseline: The Hindu calendar, Panchanga (Sanskrit: पञ्चाङ्ग) or Panjika is one of various lunisolar calendars that are traditionally used in the Indian subcontinent and Southeast Asia, with further regional variations for social and Hindu religious purposes.

prompts: The syllable Om ( which represents the Brahman and Atman ) has grown to represent Hinduism itself , while other markings such as the Swastika ( from the Sanskrit : स्वस्तिक , romanized : svastika ) a sign that represents auspiciousness , and Tilaka ( literally , seed ) on forehead – considered to be the
baseline: The syllable Om (which represents the Brahman and Atman) has grown to represent Hinduism itself, while other markings such as the Swastika (from the Sanskrit: स्वस्तिक, romanized: svastika) a sign that represents auspiciousness, and Tilaka (literally, seed) on forehead – considered to be the location of spiritual third eye, marks ceremonious welcome, blessing or one's participation in a ritual or rite of passage.

prompts: Instead , Hinduism was thought to be linked to the Hindu
baseline: Instead, Hinduism was thought to be linked to the Hindu epics and the Puranas through sects based on purohita, tantras and Bhakti.

prompts: The Hindu reform movements and the Neo - Vedanta have emphasized the Vedic heritage
baseline: The Hindu reform movements and the Neo-Vedanta have emphasized the Vedic heritage and "ancient Hinduism", and this term has been co-opted by some Hindus.

prompts: Historically , and still by some modern authors , the word ' Brahmanism ' was used in English to
baseline: Historically, and still by some modern authors, the word 'Brahmanism' was used in English to refer to the Hindu religion, treating the term Brahmanism as synonymous with Hinduism, and using it interchangeably.

prompts: The Hindu rites of cremation are seen since the Rigvedic
baseline: The Hindu rites of cremation are seen since the Rigvedic period; while they are attested from early times in the Cemetery H culture, there is a late Rigvedic reference invoking forefathers "both cremated (agnidagdhá-) and uncremated (ánagnidagdha-)". (RV 10.15.14)

prompts: In the Hindu tradition , the revered sages of this
baseline: In the Hindu tradition, the revered sages of this era were Yajnavalkya, Atharvan, Atri, Bharadvaja, Gautama Maharishi, Jamadagni, Kashyapa, Vasistha, Bhrigu, Kutsa, Pulastya, Kratu, Pulaha, Vishwamitra Narayana, Kanva, Rishabha, Vamadeva, and Angiras.

prompts: Its recitation continues to be a
baseline: Its recitation continues to be a part of Hindu wedding rituals.

prompts: According to Michaels , the period between 500 BCE and 200 BCE is a time of
baseline: According to Michaels, the period between 500 BCE and 200 BCE is a time of "ascetic reformism", while the period between 200 BCE and 1100 CE is the time of "classical Hinduism", since there is "a turning point between the Vedic religion and Hindu religions".

prompts: According to Axel Michaels , the Vedic gods declined but did not
baseline: According to Axel Michaels, the Vedic gods declined but did not disappear, and local cults were assimilated into the Vedic-Brahmanic pantheon, which changed into the Hindu pantheon.

prompts: The spread of the Vedic
baseline: The spread of the Vedic culture in the late Vedic period.

prompts: Aryavarta was limited to northwest India and the western Ganges plain , while Greater
baseline: Aryavarta was limited to northwest India and the western Ganges plain, while Greater Magadha in the east was occupied by non-Vedic Indo-Aryans.

prompts: The historical Vedic religion , also known as Vedicism and
baseline: The historical Vedic religion, also known as Vedicism and Vedism, sometimes called Ancient Hinduism, constituted the religious ideas and practices prevalent amongst the Indo-Aryan peoples of the northwest Indian subcontinent (Punjab and the western Ganges plain) during the Vedic period (1500–500 BCE).

prompts: The Vedic religion is one of the major traditions which shaped Hinduism , though
baseline: The Vedic religion is one of the major traditions which shaped Hinduism, though present-day Hinduism is significantly different from the historical Vedic religion.

prompts: The Vedic religion developed in the northwestern
baseline: The Vedic religion developed in the northwestern region of the Indian subcontinent during the early Vedic period (1500–1100 BCE), but has roots in the Eurasian Steppe Sintashta culture (2200–1800 BCE), the subsequent Central Asian Andronovo culture (2000–900 BCE), and the Indus Valley Civilisation (2600–1900 BCE).

prompts: During the late Vedic period ( 1100–500 BCE ) Brahmanism developed out of the
baseline: During the late Vedic period (1100–500 BCE) Brahmanism developed out of the Vedic religion, as an ideology of the Kuru-Panchala realm which expanded into a wider area after the demise of the Kuru-Pancala realm.

prompts: Brahmanism was one of the major influences that shaped contemporary Hinduism ,
baseline: Brahmanism was one of the major influences that shaped contemporary Hinduism, when it was synthesized with the non-Vedic Indo-Aryan religious heritage of the eastern Ganges plain (which also gave rise to Buddhism and Jainism), and with local religious traditions.

prompts: Specific rituals and sacrifices of the Vedic religion include , among others
baseline: Specific rituals and sacrifices of the Vedic religion include, among others: the Soma rituals; Fire rituals involving oblations (havir); and the Ashvamedha (horse sacrifice).

prompts: Deities emphasized in the Vedic religion include Dyaus , Indra
baseline: Deities emphasized in the Vedic religion include Dyaus, Indra, Agni, Rudra and Varuna, and important ethical concepts include satya and ṛta.

prompts: Vedism refers to the oldest form of the Vedic religion , when Indo - Aryans entered into the valley
baseline: Vedism refers to the oldest form of the Vedic religion, when Indo-Aryans entered into the valley of the Indus River in multiple waves during the 2nd millennium BCE.

prompts: According to Heinrich von Stietencron , in 19th   century western publications , the Vedic religion was believed to be different
baseline: According to Heinrich von Stietencron, in 19th century western publications, the Vedic religion was believed to be different from and unrelated to Hinduism.

prompts: In the 20th   century , a better understanding of the Vedic religion and its shared heritage and theology
baseline: In the 20th century, a better understanding of the Vedic religion and its shared heritage and theology with contemporary Hinduism led scholars to view the historical Vedic religion as ancestral to modern Hinduism.

prompts: The historical Vedic religion is now generally accepted to be a
baseline: The historical Vedic religion is now generally accepted to be a predecessor of Hinduism, but they are not the same because the textual evidence suggests significant differences between the two.

prompts: The Hindu reform movements and the Neo - Vedanta have emphasized the Vedic heritage
baseline: The Hindu reform movements and the Neo-Vedanta have emphasized the Vedic heritage and "ancient Hinduism", and this term has been co-opted by some Hindus.

prompts: The Vedic religion refers to the religious beliefs of some Vedic Indo - Aryan tribes , the aryas , who migrated into the Indus
baseline: The Vedic religion refers to the religious beliefs of some Vedic Indo-Aryan tribes, the aryas, who migrated into the Indus River valley region of the Indian subcontinent after the collapse of the Indus Valley Civilisation.

prompts: The Vedic religion , and subsequent Brahmanism , center on the myths and ritual ideologies of the Vedas , as distinguished from Agamic ,
baseline: The Vedic religion, and subsequent Brahmanism, center on the myths and ritual ideologies of the Vedas, as distinguished from Agamic, Tantric and sectarian forms of Indian religion, which take recourse to the authority of non-Vedic textual sources.

prompts: The Vedic religion is described in the Vedas and associated with voluminous Vedic
baseline: The Vedic religion is described in the Vedas and associated with voluminous Vedic literature, including the early Upanishads, preserved into the modern times by the different priestly schools.

prompts: The religion existed in the western Ganges plain in the early Vedic period from c. 1500–1100   BCE , and developed into Brahmanism in
baseline: The religion existed in the western Ganges plain in the early Vedic period from c. 1500–1100 BCE, and developed into Brahmanism in the late Vedic period (1100–500 BCE).

prompts: The commonly proposed period of earlier Vedic age is dated back to 2nd
baseline: The commonly proposed period of earlier Vedic age is dated back to 2nd millennium BCE.

prompts: The Vedic beliefs and practices of the pre - classical era were closely related to the hypothesized
baseline: The Vedic beliefs and practices of the pre-classical era were closely related to the hypothesized Proto-Indo-European religion, and shows relations with rituals from the Andronovo culture, from which the Indo-Aryan people descended.

prompts: The Vedic religion was the product of
baseline: The Vedic religion was the product of "a composite of the Indo-Aryan and Harappan cultures and civilizations".

prompts: White ( 2003 ) cites three other scholars who " have emphatically demonstrated " that Vedic
baseline: White (2003) cites three other scholars who "have emphatically demonstrated" that Vedic religion is partially derived from the Indus Valley civilization.

prompts: It is unclear if the theory in diverse Vedic texts actually reflect the folk practices
baseline: It is unclear if the theory in diverse Vedic texts actually reflect the folk practices, iconography, and other practical aspects of the Vedic religion.

prompts: The Vedic religion changed when Indo - Aryan people migrated into the Ganges
baseline: The Vedic religion changed when Indo-Aryan people migrated into the Ganges Plain after c. 1100 BCE and became settled farmers, further syncretizing with the native cultures of northern India.

prompts: The evidence suggests that the Vedic religion evolved in " two
baseline: The evidence suggests that the Vedic religion evolved in "two superficially contradictory directions", namely an ever more "elaborate, expensive, and specialized system of rituals", which survives in the present-day srauta-ritual, and "abstraction and internalization of the principles underlying ritual and cosmic speculation" within oneself, akin to the Jain and Buddhist tradition.

prompts: Aspects of the historical Vedic religion still continue in modern times
baseline: Aspects of the historical Vedic religion still continue in modern times.

prompts: For instance , the Nambudiri Brahmins continue the ancient Śrauta
baseline: For instance, the Nambudiri Brahmins continue the ancient Śrauta rituals, and the complex Vedic rituals of Śrauta are practiced in Kerala and coastal Andhra.

prompts: The Kalash people residing in northwest Pakistan also continue to practice a
baseline: The Kalash people residing in northwest Pakistan also continue to practice a form of the ancient Vedic religion.

prompts: It has also been suggested by Michael Witzel that Shinto , the native religion of Japan , contains some influences from
baseline: It has also been suggested by Michael Witzel that Shinto, the native religion of Japan, contains some influences from the ancient Vedic religion.

prompts: Brahmanism , also called Brahminism , developed out of the
baseline: Brahmanism, also called Brahminism, developed out of the Vedic religion, incorporating non-Vedic religious ideas, and expanding to a region stretching from the northwest Indian subcontinent to the Ganges valley.

prompts: Brahmanism included the Vedic corpus , but also post - Vedic texts such as the Dharmasutras and Dharmasastras , which gave prominence to the
baseline: Brahmanism included the Vedic corpus, but also post-Vedic texts such as the Dharmasutras and Dharmasastras, which gave prominence to the priestly (Brahmin) class of the society, Heesterman also mentions the post-Vedic Smriti (Puranas and the Epics), which are also incorporated in the later Smarta tradition.

baseline: The name India itself is derived from Sanskrit Sindhu, the historic local appellation for the Indus River.

prompts: Its followers are called Hindus , who refer to it as
baseline: Its followers are called Hindus, who refer to it as Sanātana Dharma (Sanskrit: सनातनधर्मः, lit. 'the eternal law that sustains/upholds/surely preserves'), amongst many other expressions.

prompts: The word Hindu is an exonym , and while Hinduism has been called the oldest religion
baseline: The word Hindu is an exonym, and while Hinduism has been called the oldest religion in the world, it has also been described as sanātana dharma (Sanskrit: सनातन धर्म, lit. ''the eternal dharma''), a modern usage, based on the belief that its origins lie beyond human history, as revealed in the Hindu texts.

prompts: The major Hindu denominations are Vaishnavism , Shaivism
baseline: The major Hindu denominations are Vaishnavism, Shaivism, Shaktism, and the Smarta tradition.

baseline: The six Āstika schools of Hindu philosophy, which recognise the authority of the Vedas, are: Sānkhya, Yoga, Nyāya, Vaisheshika, Mimāmsā, and Vedānta.

prompts: Hindu texts have been classified into Śruti (
baseline: Hindu texts have been classified into Śruti ("heard") and Smṛti ("remembered").

baseline: The major Hindu scriptures are the Vedas, the Upanishads, the Purānas, the Mahābhārata, the Rāmāyana, and the Āgamas.

prompts: Prominent themes in Hindu beliefs include karma ( action
baseline: Prominent themes in Hindu beliefs include karma (action, intent and consequences) and the four Puruṣārthas, proper goals or aims of human life, namely: dharma (ethics/duties), artha (prosperity/work), kama (desires/passions) and moksha (liberation/freedom from the passions and the cycle of death and rebirth).

prompts: Hindu religious practices include devotion ( bhakti
baseline: Hindu religious practices include devotion (bhakti), worship (puja), sacrificial rites (yajña), and meditation (dhyāna) and yoga.

baseline: Significant numbers of Hindu communities are found in other countries of South Asia, in Southeast Asia, in the Caribbean, Middle East, North America, Europe, Oceania, Africa, and other regions.

baseline: According to Gavin Flood, "The actual term Hindu first occurs as a Persian geographical term for the people who lived beyond the river Indus (Sanskrit: Sindhu)", more specifically in the 6th-century BCE inscription of Darius I (550–486 BCE).

prompts: The term Hindu in these ancient records is a geographical term
baseline: The term Hindu in these ancient records is a geographical term and did not refer to a religion.

baseline: The word Hindu is found as heptahindu in Avesta – equivalent to Rigvedic sapta sindhu, while hndstn (pronounced Hindustan) is found in a Sasanian inscription from the 3rd century CE, both of which refer to parts of northwestern South Asia.

prompts: Among the earliest known records of ' Hindu ' with connotations of religion may be in the 7th
baseline: Among the earliest known records of 'Hindu' with connotations of religion may be in the 7th-century CE Chinese text Record of the Western Regions by Xuanzang, and 14th-century Persian text Futuhu's-salatin by 'Abd al-Malik Isami.

baseline: Some 16–18th century Bengali Gaudiya Vaishnava texts mention Hindu and Hindu dharma to distinguish from Muslims without positively defining these terms.

baseline: According to Mahatma Gandhi, "a man may not believe in God and still call himself a Hindu".

baseline: The six āstika schools of Hindu philosophy, which recognise the authority of the Vedas are: Sānkhya, Yoga, Nyāya, Vaisheshika, Mimāmsā, and Vedānta.

prompts: The major kinds , according to McDaniel are Folk Hinduism ,
baseline: The major kinds, according to McDaniel are Folk Hinduism, based on local traditions and cults of local deities and is the oldest, non-literate system; Vedic Hinduism based on the earliest layers of the Vedas, traceable to the 2nd millennium BCE; Vedantic Hinduism based on the philosophy of the Upanishads, including Advaita Vedanta, emphasising knowledge and wisdom; Yogic Hinduism, following the text of Yoga Sutras of Patanjali emphasising introspective awareness; Dharmic Hinduism or "daily morality", which McDaniel states is stereotyped in some books as the "only form of Hindu religion with a belief in karma, cows and caste"; and bhakti or devotional Hinduism, where intense emotions are elaborately incorporated in the pursuit of the spiritual.

prompts: Michaels distinguishes three Hindu religions
baseline: Michaels distinguishes three Hindu religions and four forms of Hindu religiosity.

prompts: The four forms of Hindu religiosity are the classical "
baseline: The four forms of Hindu religiosity are the classical "karma-marga", jnana-marga, bhakti-marga, and "heroism", which is rooted in militaristic traditions.

baseline: According to Michaels, one out of nine Hindu belongs by birth to one or both of the Brahmanic-Sanskritic Hinduism and Folk religion typology, whether practising or non-practicing.

baseline: Srirangam Ranganathaswamy Temple dedicated to the Hindu deity Vishnu is said to be worshiped by Ikshvaku (and the descendants of Ikshvaku Vamsam).

baseline: All aspects of a Hindu life, namely acquiring wealth (artha), fulfilment of desires (kama), and attaining liberation (moksha), are viewed here as part of "dharma", which encapsulates the "right way of living" and eternal harmonious principles in their fulfilment.

prompts: The use of the term Sanātana Dharma for Hinduism is a modern usage
baseline: The use of the term Sanātana Dharma for Hinduism is a modern usage, based on the belief that the origins of Hinduism lie beyond human history, as revealed in the Hindu texts.

baseline: These duties applied regardless of a Hindu's class, caste, or sect, and they contrasted with svadharma, one's "own duty", in accordance with one's class or caste (varṇa) and stage in life (puruṣārtha).

baseline: In recent years, the term has been used by Hindu leaders, reformers, and nationalists to refer to Hinduism.

baseline: Whatever the case, many Hindu religious sources see persons or groups which they consider as non-Vedic (and which reject Vedic varṇāśrama – 'caste and life stage' orthodoxy) as being heretics (pāṣaṇḍa/pākhaṇḍa).

baseline: Some in the Mimamsa school of Hindu philosophy considered the Agamas such as the Pancaratrika to be invalid because it did not conform to the Vedas.

baseline: Though many religious Hindus implicitly acknowledge the authority of the Vedas, this acknowledgment is often "no more than a declaration that someone considers himself  a Hindu," and "most Indians today pay lip service to the Veda and have no regard for the contents of the text." Some Hindus challenge the authority of the Vedas, thereby implicitly acknowledging its importance to the history of Hinduism, states Lipner.

prompts: It was quoted by the Indian
baseline: It was quoted by the Indian Supreme Court in 1966, and again in 1995, "as an 'adequate and satisfactory definition," and is still the legal definition of a Hindu today.

baseline: Hindu beliefs are vast and diverse, and thus Hinduism is often referred to as a family of religions rather than a single religion.

baseline: Unlike other religions in the World, the Hindu religion does not claim any one Prophet, it does not worship any one God, it does not believe in any one philosophic concept, it does not follow any one act of religious rites or performances; in fact, it does not satisfy the traditional features of a religion or creed.

baseline: Theism is also difficult to use as a unifying doctrine for Hinduism, because while some Hindu philosophies postulate a theistic ontology of creation, other Hindus are or have been atheists.

baseline: Brahmins played an essential role in the development of the post-Vedic Hindu synthesis, disseminating Vedic culture to local communities, and integrating local religiosity into the trans-regional Brahmanic culture.

baseline: Pashupatinath Temple in Nepal dedicated to the Hindu deity Shiva as the lord of all beings

baseline: According to Nicholson, already between the 12th and the 16th centuries "certain thinkers began to treat as a single whole the diverse philosophical teachings of the Upanishads, epics, Puranas, and the schools known retrospectively as the 'six systems' (saddarsana) of mainstream Hindu philosophy." baseline: Lorenzen locates the origins of a distinct Hindu identity in the interaction between Muslims and Hindus, and a process of "mutual self-definition with a contrasting Muslim other", which started well before 1800.

baseline: As a counteraction to Islamic supremacy and as part of the continuing process of regionalization, two religious innovations developed in the Hindu religions: the formation of sects and a historicization which preceded later nationalism ... aints and sometimes militant sect leaders, such as the Marathi poet Tukaram (1609–1649) and Ramdas (1608–1681), articulated ideas in which they glorified Hinduism and the past.

baseline: Scholars such as Pennington state that the colonial polemical reports led to fabricated stereotypes where Hinduism was mere mystic paganism devoted to the service of devils, while other scholars state that the colonial constructions influenced the belief that the Vedas, Bhagavad Gita, Manusmriti and such texts were the essence of Hindu religiosity, and in the modern association of 'Hindu doctrine' with the schools of Vedanta (in particular Advaita Vedanta) as a paradigmatic example of Hinduism's mystical nature".

baseline: This inclusivism was further developed in the 19th and 20th centuries by Hindu reform movements and Neo-Vedanta, and has become characteristic of modern Hinduism.

baseline: Major representatives of "Hindu modernism" are Ram Mohan Roy, Swami Vivekananda, Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan and Mahatma Gandhi.

baseline: Raja Rammohan Roy is known as the father of the Hindu Renaissance.

prompts: He was a major influence on Swami Vivekananda , who , according to Flood ,
baseline: He was a major influence on Swami Vivekananda, who, according to Flood, was "a figure of great importance in the development of a modern Hindu self-understanding and in formulating the West's view of Hinduism".

baseline: And there are assumptions of political dominance of Hindu nationalism in India, also known as 'Neo-Hindutva'.

baseline: Prominent themes in Hindu beliefs include (but are not restricted to) Dharma (ethics/duties), saṃsāra (the continuing cycle of entanglement in passions and the resulting birth, life, death, and rebirth), Karma (action, intent, and consequences), moksha (liberation from attachment and saṃsāra), and the various yogas (paths or practices).

baseline: Classical Hindu thought accepts four proper goals or aims of human life, known as Puruṣārthas – Dharma, Artha, Kama and Moksha.

baseline: Hindu dharma includes the religious duties, moral rights and duties of each individual, as well as behaviours that enable social order, right conduct, and those that are virtuous.

baseline: A central premise of Hindu philosophy is that every person should live a joyous, pleasurable and fulfilling life, where every person's needs are acknowledged and fulfilled.

baseline: The Hindu scriptures name celestial entities called Devas (or Devi in feminine form), which may be translated into English as gods or heavenly beings.

baseline: The Yoga school of Hinduism accepted the concept of a "personal god" and left it to the Hindu to define his or her god.

baseline: Hindu temples and domestic altars, are important elements of worship in contemporary theistic Hinduism.

baseline: Concurrent Hindu practices include a belief in god-without-attributes (nirguna Brahman), and god within oneself.

baseline: Hindu festivals (Sanskrit: Utsava; literally: "to lift higher") are ceremonies that weave individual and social life to dharma.

baseline: Hinduism has many festivals throughout the year, where the dates are set by the lunisolar Hindu calendar, many coinciding with either the full moon (Holi) or the new moon (Diwali), often with seasonal changes.

baseline: Some festivals are found only regionally and they celebrate local traditions, while a few such as Holi and Diwali are pan-Hindu.

baseline: The same festival sometimes marks different stories depending on the Hindu denomination, and the celebrations incorporate regional themes, traditional agriculture, local arts, family get togethers, Puja rituals and feasts.

baseline: According to the Hindu text Skanda Purana, Tirtha are of three kinds: Jangam Tirtha is to a place movable of a sadhu, a rishi, a guru; Sthawar Tirtha is to a place immovable, like Benaras, Haridwar, Mount Kailash, holy rivers; while Manas Tirtha is to a place of mind of truth, charity, patience, compassion, soft speech, Self.

baseline: The proper procedure for a pilgrimage is widely discussed in Hindu texts.

baseline: Hindu architecture is the traditional system of Indian architecture for structures such as temples, monasteries, statues, homes, market places, gardens and town planning as described in Hindu texts.

baseline: Far fewer secular Hindu architecture have survived into the modern era, such as palaces, homes and cities.

baseline: Hindu art encompasses the artistic traditions and styles culturally connected to Hinduism and have a long history of religious association with Hindu scriptures, rituals and worship.

prompts: The Hindu calendar , Panchanga ( Sanskrit : पञ्चाङ्ग ) or Panjika is one of various
baseline: The Hindu calendar, Panchanga (Sanskrit: पञ्चाङ्ग) or Panjika is one of various lunisolar calendars that are traditionally used in the Indian subcontinent and Southeast Asia, with further regional variations for social and Hindu religious purposes.

prompts: Of the various regional calendars , the most studied and known Hindu calendars are
baseline: Of the various regional calendars, the most studied and known Hindu calendars are the Shalivahana Shaka (Based on the King Shalivahana, also the Indian national calendar) found in the Deccan region of Southern India and the Vikram Samvat (Bikrami) found in Nepal and the North and Central regions of India – both of which emphasise the lunar cycle.

prompts: In regions such as Tamil Nadu and Kerala , the solar cycle is emphasised and this is
baseline: In regions such as Tamil Nadu and Kerala, the solar cycle is emphasised and this is called the Tamil calendar (though Tamil calendar uses month names like in Hindu Calendar) and Malayalam calendar and these have origins in the second half of the 1st millennium CE.

prompts: A Hindu calendar is sometimes referred to as Panchangam ( पञ्चाङ्गम् ) , which is also known as Panjika in
baseline: A Hindu calendar is sometimes referred to as Panchangam (पञ्चाङ्गम्), which is also known as Panjika in Eastern India.

prompts: The ancient Hindu calendar conceptual design is also found in the Hebrew
baseline: The ancient Hindu calendar conceptual design is also found in the Hebrew calendar, the Chinese calendar, and the Babylonian calendar, but different from the Gregorian calendar.

prompts: Unlike the Gregorian calendar which adds additional days to the month to adjust for the mismatch
baseline: Unlike the Gregorian calendar which adds additional days to the month to adjust for the mismatch between twelve lunar cycles (354 lunar days) and nearly 365 solar days, the Hindu calendar maintains the integrity of the lunar month, but inserts an extra full month, once every 32–33 months, to ensure that the festivals and crop-related rituals fall in the appropriate season.

prompts: The Hindu calendars have been in use in the Indian subcontinent since Vedic times , and remain in use by
baseline: The Hindu calendars have been in use in the Indian subcontinent since Vedic times, and remain in use by the Hindus all over the world, particularly to set Hindu festival dates.

prompts: The Buddhist calendar and the traditional lunisolar calendars of Cambodia , Laos , Myanmar , Sri Lanka and Thailand are also based on an older
baseline: The Buddhist calendar and the traditional lunisolar calendars of Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, Sri Lanka and Thailand are also based on an older version of the Hindu calendar.

prompts: Similarly , the ancient Jain traditions have followed the same lunisolar
baseline: Similarly, the ancient Jain traditions have followed the same lunisolar system as the Hindu calendar for festivals, texts and inscriptions.

prompts: The Hindu calendar is also important to
baseline: The Hindu calendar is also important to the practice of Hindu astrology and zodiac system.

prompts: In whatever way a Hindu defines the goal of life , there are several methods (
baseline: In whatever way a Hindu defines the goal of life, there are several methods (yogas) that sages have taught for reaching that goal.

prompts: Yoga is a Hindu discipline which trains the body ,
baseline: Yoga is a Hindu discipline which trains the body, mind, and consciousness for health, tranquility, and spiritual insight.

baseline: The cow in Hindu society is traditionally identified as a caretaker and a maternal figure, and Hindu society honours the cow as a symbol of unselfish giving, selfless sacrifice, gentleness and tolerance.

baseline: There are many Hindu groups that have continued to abide by a strict vegetarian diet in modern times.

baseline: Food affects body, mind and spirit in Hindu beliefs.

baseline: Hindu texts such as Śāṇḍilya Upanishad and Svātmārāma recommend Mitahara (eating in moderation) as one of the Yamas (virtuous Self restraints).

baseline: A Hindu temple is a house of god(s).

baseline: A temple incorporates all elements of Hindu cosmology, the highest spire or dome representing Mount Meru – reminder of the abode of Brahma and the center of spiritual universe, the carvings and iconography symbolically presenting dharma, kama, artha, moksha and karma.

prompts: Hindu temples are spiritual destinations for
baseline: Hindu temples are spiritual destinations for many Hindus (not all), as well as landmarks for arts, annual festivals, rite of passage rituals, and community celebrations.

baseline: Hindu temples come in many styles, diverse locations, deploy different construction methods and are adapted to different deities and regional beliefs.

baseline: Two major styles of Hindu temples include the Gopuram style found in south India, and Nagara style found in north India.

baseline: Yet, despite their differences, almost all Hindu temples share certain common architectural principles, core ideas, symbolism and themes.

baseline: Kauai Hindu monastery in Kauai Island in Hawaii is the only Hindu Monastery in the North American continent.

prompts: Traditionally the life of a Hindu is divided into four Āśramas
baseline: Traditionally the life of a Hindu is divided into four Āśramas (phases or life stages; another meaning includes monastery).

prompts: Grihastha stage starts with Hindu wedding , and has been considered the most important
baseline: Grihastha stage starts with Hindu wedding, and has been considered the most important of all stages in sociological context, as Hindus in this stage not only pursued a virtuous life, they produced food and wealth that sustained people in other stages of life, as well as the offsprings that continued mankind.

prompts: Combined with four proper goals of human life ( Purusartha ) , the Ashramas system traditionally aimed at
baseline: Combined with four proper goals of human life (Purusartha), the Ashramas system traditionally aimed at providing a Hindu with fulfilling life and spiritual liberation.

baseline: A Hindu monk is called a Sanyāsī, Sādhu, or Swāmi.

baseline: Renunciates receive high respect in Hindu society because of their simple ahiṃsā-driven lifestyle and dedication to spiritual liberation (moksha) – believed to be the ultimate goal of life in Hinduism.

prompts: The subsequent period , between 800 BCE and 200 BCE , is " a turning
baseline: The subsequent period, between 800 BCE and 200 BCE, is "a turning point between the Vedic religion and Hindu religions", and a formative period for Hinduism, Jainism and Buddhism.

baseline: In this period the six branches of Hindu philosophy evolved, namely Samkhya, Yoga, Nyaya, Vaisheshika, Mīmāṃsā, and Vedanta.

prompts: The Hindu Shore Temple at Mahabalipuram was built by Narasimhavarman II
baseline: The Hindu Shore Temple at Mahabalipuram was built by Narasimhavarman II.

baseline: Hinduism under both Hindu and Islamic rulers from c. 1250–1750 CE, saw the increasing prominence of the Bhakti movement, which remains influential today.

prompts: The colonial period saw the emergence of various Hindu reform movements partly inspired by western movements
baseline: The colonial period saw the emergence of various Hindu reform movements partly inspired by western movements, such as Unitarianism and Theosophy.

prompts: The Partition of India in 1947 was along religious lines
baseline: The Partition of India in 1947 was along religious lines, with the Republic of India emerging with a Hindu majority.

baseline: During the 20th century, due to the Indian diaspora, Hindu minorities have formed in all continents, with the largest communities in absolute numbers in the United States, and the United Kingdom.

prompts: Religious leaders of some Hindu reform movements such as the Arya Samaj launched Shuddhi movement to
baseline: Religious leaders of some Hindu reform movements such as the Arya Samaj launched Shuddhi movement to proselytise and reconvert Muslims and Christians back to Hinduism, while those such as the Brahmo Samaj suggested Hinduism to be a non-missionary religion.

prompts: There have also been an increase of
baseline: There have also been an increase of Hindu identity in politics, mostly in India, Nepal and Bangladesh in the form of Hindutva.

baseline: The revivalist movement was mainly started and encouraged by many organisations like RSS, BJP and other organisations of Sangh Parivar in India, while there are also many Hindu nationalist parties and organisations such as Shivsena Nepal and RPP in Nepal, HINDRAF in Malaysia, etc.

prompts: India contains 94 % of
baseline: India contains 94% of the global Hindu population.

prompts: The word Hindū is an exonym , and is derived from the Sanskrit
baseline: The word Hindū is an exonym, and is derived from the Sanskrit root Sindhu, believed to be the name of the Indus River in the northwestern part of the Indian subcontinent.

prompts: This Arabic term was itself taken from the pre
baseline: This Arabic term was itself taken from the pre-Islamic Persian term Hindū.

prompts: The major kinds , according to McDaniel are Folk Hinduism ,
baseline: The major kinds, according to McDaniel are Folk Hinduism, based on local traditions and cults of local deities and is the oldest, non-literate system; Vedic Hinduism based on the earliest layers of the Vedas, traceable to the 2nd millennium BCE; Vedantic Hinduism based on the philosophy of the Upanishads, including Advaita Vedanta, emphasising knowledge and wisdom; Yogic Hinduism, following the text of Yoga Sutras of Patanjali emphasising introspective awareness; Dharmic Hinduism or "daily morality", which McDaniel states is stereotyped in some books as the "only form of Hindu religion with a belief in karma, cows and caste"; and bhakti or devotional Hinduism, where intense emotions are elaborately incorporated in the pursuit of the spiritual.

prompts: To many Hindus , Hinduism is a tradition that can be traced at least to
baseline: To many Hindus, Hinduism is a tradition that can be traced at least to the ancient Vedic era.

prompts: Whatever the case , many Hindu religious sources see persons or groups
baseline: Whatever the case, many Hindu religious sources see persons or groups which they consider as non-Vedic (and which reject Vedic varṇāśrama – 'caste and life stage' orthodoxy) as being heretics (pāṣaṇḍa/pākhaṇḍa).

prompts: However , adds Sanderson , this Shaiva ascetic tradition viewed themselves as being
baseline: However, adds Sanderson, this Shaiva ascetic tradition viewed themselves as being genuinely true to the Vedic tradition and "held unanimously that the Śruti and Smṛti of Brahmanism are universally and uniquely valid in their own sphere,  and that as such they  are man's sole means of valid knowledge ".

prompts: The Vaidika dharma or " Vedic way of life " , states Lipner , does not mean " Hinduism is
baseline: The Vaidika dharma or "Vedic way of life", states Lipner, does not mean "Hinduism is necessarily religious" or that Hindus have a universally accepted "conventional or institutional meaning" for that term.

prompts: Brahmins played an essential role in the development of the post - Vedic Hindu synthesis , disseminating Vedic culture to
baseline: Brahmins played an essential role in the development of the post-Vedic Hindu synthesis, disseminating Vedic culture to local communities, and integrating local religiosity into the trans-regional Brahmanic culture.

prompts: In the post - Gupta period Vedanta developed in southern India
baseline: In the post-Gupta period Vedanta developed in southern India, where orthodox Brahmanic culture and the Hindu culture were preserved, building on ancient Vedic traditions while "accommoda the multiple demands of Hinduism."

prompts: Lorenzen traces the emergence of a " family resemblance " , and what he calls as " beginnings
baseline: Lorenzen traces the emergence of a "family resemblance", and what he calls as "beginnings of medieval and modern Hinduism" taking shape, at c. 300–600 CE, with the development of the early Puranas, and continuities with the earlier Vedic religion.

prompts: Beginning in the 19th century , Indian modernists re - asserted Hinduism
baseline: Beginning in the 19th century, Indian modernists re-asserted Hinduism as a major asset of Indian civilisation, meanwhile "purifying" Hinduism from its Tantric elements and elevating the Vedic elements.

prompts: Of the Shrutis ( Vedic corpus ) , the Upanishads alone are widely influential among
baseline: Of the Shrutis (Vedic corpus), the Upanishads alone are widely influential among Hindus, considered scriptures par excellence of Hinduism, and their central ideas have continued to influence its thoughts and traditions.

prompts: Since the 19th - century Indian modernists have re - asserted the
baseline: Since the 19th-century Indian modernists have re-asserted the 'Aryan origins' of Hinduism, "purifying" Hinduism from its Tantric elements and elevating the Vedic elements.

prompts: Karma translates literally as action , work , or deed , and also
baseline: Karma translates literally as action, work, or deed, and also refers to a Vedic theory of "moral law of cause and effect".

prompts: The later Vedic texts such as the Aranyakas and the Upanisads show a different soteriology
baseline: The later Vedic texts such as the Aranyakas and the Upanisads show a different soteriology based on reincarnation, they show little concern with ancestor rites, and they begin to philosophically interpret the earlier rituals.

prompts: The idea of reincarnation and karma have roots in the
baseline: The idea of reincarnation and karma have roots in the Upanishads of the late Vedic period, predating the Buddha and the Mahavira.

prompts: The " One Truth " of Vedic literature , in modern era scholarship , has been interpreted as monotheism ,
baseline: The "One Truth" of Vedic literature, in modern era scholarship, has been interpreted as monotheism, monism, as well as a deified Hidden Principles behind the great happenings and processes of nature.

prompts: This perception of divinity manifested in all things , as Buttimer and Wallin view it , makes
baseline: This perception of divinity manifested in all things, as Buttimer and Wallin view it, makes the Vedic foundations of Hinduism quite distinct from animism, in which all things are themselves divine.

prompts: The Vedic view does not perceive this competition , equality of man to nature , or multiplicity so much as an overwhelming and interconnecting single divinity that
baseline: The Vedic view does not perceive this competition, equality of man to nature, or multiplicity so much as an overwhelming and interconnecting single divinity that unifies everyone and everything.

prompts: The word avatar does not appear in the Vedic literature ;   It appears in verb forms
baseline: The word avatar does not appear in the Vedic literature;  It appears in verb forms in post-Vedic literature, and as a noun particularly in the Puranic literature after the 6th century CE.

prompts: A typical Hindu wedding is solemnised before Vedic fire
baseline: A typical Hindu wedding is solemnised before Vedic fire ritual (shown).

prompts: Vedic rituals of fire - oblation ( yajna ) and chanting of Vedic hymns
baseline: Vedic rituals of fire-oblation (yajna) and chanting of Vedic hymns are observed on special occasions, such as a Hindu wedding.

prompts: Other major life - stage events , such as rituals after death , include the yajña and
baseline: Other major life-stage events, such as rituals after death, include the yajña and chanting of Vedic mantras.

prompts: The words of the mantras are " themselves sacred , " and " do not constitute linguistic utterances .
baseline: The words of the mantras are "themselves sacred," and "do not constitute linguistic utterances." Instead, as Klostermaier notes, in their application in Vedic rituals they become magical sounds, "means to an end." In the Brahmanical perspective, the sounds have their own meaning, mantras are considered "primordial rhythms of creation", preceding the forms to which they refer.

prompts: The Hindu calendars have been in use in the Indian subcontinent since Vedic times , and remain in use by
baseline: The Hindu calendars have been in use in the Indian subcontinent since Vedic times, and remain in use by the Hindus all over the world, particularly to set Hindu festival dates.

prompts: Early Buddhist communities of India adopted the ancient Vedic
baseline: Early Buddhist communities of India adopted the ancient Vedic calendar, later Vikrami calendar and then local Buddhist calendars.

prompts: They are the Brahmins :
baseline: They are the Brahmins: Vedic teachers and priests; the Kshatriyas: warriors and kings; the Vaishyas: farmers and merchants; and the Shudras: servants and labourers.

prompts: While the traditional Itihasa - Purana   and the Epic - Puranic chronology derived from it present
baseline: While the traditional Itihasa-Purana  and the Epic-Puranic chronology derived from it present Hinduism as a tradition existing for thousands of years, scholars regard Hinduism as a synthesis of various Indian cultures and traditions, with diverse roots and no single founder, which emerged after the Vedic period, between c. 500–200 BCE and c. 300 CE.

prompts: The first period is the pre - Vedic period , which includes the Indus Valley
baseline: The first period is the pre-Vedic period, which includes the Indus Valley Civilization and local pre-historic religions, ending at about 1750 BCE.

baseline: The architectural guidelines survive in Sanskrit manuscripts and in some cases also in other regional languages.

baseline: This "Global Hinduism" has a worldwide appeal, transcending national boundaries and, according to Flood, "becoming a world religion alongside Christianity, Islam and Buddhism", both for the Hindu diaspora communities and for westerners who are attracted to non-western cultures and religions.

baseline: In addition, in antiquity and the Middle Ages, Hinduism was the state religion in many Indianized kingdoms of Asia, the Greater India – from Afghanistan (Kabul) in the West and including almost all of Southeast Asia in the East (Cambodia, Vietnam, Indonesia, partly Philippines) – and only by the 15th century was nearly everywhere supplanted by Buddhism and Islam, except several still Hindu minor Austronesian ethnic groups, such as the Balinese and Tenggerese people in Indonesia, and the Chams in Vietnam.

baseline: The subsequent period, between 800 BCE and 200 BCE, is "a turning point between the Vedic religion and Hindu religions", and a formative period for Hinduism, Jainism and Buddhism.

baseline: The Hindu rites of cremation are seen since the Rigvedic period; while they are attested from early times in the Cemetery H culture, there is a late Rigvedic reference invoking forefathers "both cremated (agnidagdhá-) and uncremated (ánagnidagdha-)". (RV 10.15.14)

baseline: The spread of the Vedic culture in the late Vedic period.

baseline: Aryavarta was limited to northwest India and the western Ganges plain, while Greater Magadha in the east was occupied by non-Vedic Indo-Aryans.

prompts: The historical Vedic religion , also known as Vedicism and
baseline: The historical Vedic religion, also known as Vedicism and Vedism, sometimes called Ancient Hinduism, constituted the religious ideas and practices prevalent amongst the Indo-Aryan peoples of the northwest Indian subcontinent (Punjab and the western Ganges plain) during the Vedic period (1500–500 BCE).

prompts: The Vedic religion is one of the major traditions which shaped Hinduism , though
baseline: The Vedic religion is one of the major traditions which shaped Hinduism, though present-day Hinduism is significantly different from the historical Vedic religion.

prompts: The Vedic religion developed in the northwestern
baseline: The Vedic religion developed in the northwestern region of the Indian subcontinent during the early Vedic period (1500–1100 BCE), but has roots in the Eurasian Steppe Sintashta culture (2200–1800 BCE), the subsequent Central Asian Andronovo culture (2000–900 BCE), and the Indus Valley Civilisation (2600–1900 BCE).

prompts: During the late Vedic period ( 1100–500 BCE ) Brahmanism developed out of the
baseline: During the late Vedic period (1100–500 BCE) Brahmanism developed out of the Vedic religion, as an ideology of the Kuru-Panchala realm which expanded into a wider area after the demise of the Kuru-Pancala realm.

prompts: Brahmanism was one of the major influences that shaped contemporary Hinduism ,
baseline: Brahmanism was one of the major influences that shaped contemporary Hinduism, when it was synthesized with the non-Vedic Indo-Aryan religious heritage of the eastern Ganges plain (which also gave rise to Buddhism and Jainism), and with local religious traditions.

baseline: Specific rituals and sacrifices of the Vedic religion include, among others: the Soma rituals; Fire rituals involving oblations (havir); and the Ashvamedha (horse sacrifice).

baseline: Deities emphasized in the Vedic religion include Dyaus, Indra, Agni, Rudra and Varuna, and important ethical concepts include satya and ṛta.

baseline: In the 20th century, a better understanding of the Vedic religion and its shared heritage and theology with contemporary Hinduism led scholars to view the historical Vedic religion as ancestral to modern Hinduism.

prompts: The historical Vedic religion is now generally accepted to be a
baseline: The historical Vedic religion is now generally accepted to be a predecessor of Hinduism, but they are not the same because the textual evidence suggests significant differences between the two.

baseline: The Vedic religion, and subsequent Brahmanism, center on the myths and ritual ideologies of the Vedas, as distinguished from Agamic, Tantric and sectarian forms of Indian religion, which take recourse to the authority of non-Vedic textual sources.

baseline: The Vedic religion is described in the Vedas and associated with voluminous Vedic literature, including the early Upanishads, preserved into the modern times by the different priestly schools.

baseline: The religion existed in the western Ganges plain in the early Vedic period from c. 1500–1100 BCE, and developed into Brahmanism in the late Vedic period (1100–500 BCE).

baseline: The evidence suggests that the Vedic religion evolved in "two superficially contradictory directions", namely an ever more "elaborate, expensive, and specialized system of rituals", which survives in the present-day srauta-ritual, and "abstraction and internalization of the principles underlying ritual and cosmic speculation" within oneself, akin to the Jain and Buddhist tradition.

baseline: Aspects of the historical Vedic religion still continue in modern times.

baseline: The scriptures of Hinduism are the Shrutis (the four Vedas, which comprise the original Vedic Hymns, or Samhitas, and three tiers of commentaries upon the Samhitas, namely the Brahmanas, Aranyakas and Upanishads); Furthermore, Hinduism is also based on the Smritis (including the Rāmāyana, the Bhagavad Gītā , and the Purānas), which are considered to be of secondary authority and of human creation of sages but the 18 Puranas.

baseline: As far as citizens are concerned, only 7 out of 20 Indian Hindus are in favor of making India a Hindu Nation.

baseline: The Vedic culture developed in India in 1500 BCE and 500 BCE.

baseline: The name India itself is derived from Sanskrit Sindhu, the historic local appellation for the Indus River.

prompts: Its followers are called Hindus , who refer to it as
baseline: Its followers are called Hindus, who refer to it as Sanātana Dharma (Sanskrit: सनातनधर्मः, lit. 'the eternal law that sustains/upholds/surely preserves'), amongst many other expressions.

prompts: The word Hindu is an exonym , and while Hinduism has been called the oldest religion
baseline: The word Hindu is an exonym, and while Hinduism has been called the oldest religion in the world, it has also been described as sanātana dharma (Sanskrit: सनातन धर्म, lit. ''the eternal dharma''), a modern usage, based on the belief that its origins lie beyond human history, as revealed in the Hindu texts.

prompts: The major Hindu denominations are Vaishnavism , Shaivism
baseline: The major Hindu denominations are Vaishnavism, Shaivism, Shaktism, and the Smarta tradition.

baseline: The six Āstika schools of Hindu philosophy, which recognise the authority of the Vedas, are: Sānkhya, Yoga, Nyāya, Vaisheshika, Mimāmsā, and Vedānta.

prompts: Hindu texts have been classified into Śruti (
baseline: Hindu texts have been classified into Śruti ("heard") and Smṛti ("remembered").

prompts: The major Hindu scriptures are the Vedas ,
baseline: The major Hindu scriptures are the Vedas, the Upanishads, the Purānas, the Mahābhārata, the Rāmāyana, and the Āgamas.

prompts: Prominent themes in Hindu beliefs include karma ( action
baseline: Prominent themes in Hindu beliefs include karma (action, intent and consequences) and the four Puruṣārthas, proper goals or aims of human life, namely: dharma (ethics/duties), artha (prosperity/work), kama (desires/passions) and moksha (liberation/freedom from the passions and the cycle of death and rebirth).

prompts: Hindu religious practices include devotion ( bhakti
baseline: Hindu religious practices include devotion (bhakti), worship (puja), sacrificial rites (yajña), and meditation (dhyāna) and yoga.

baseline: Significant numbers of Hindu communities are found in other countries of South Asia, in Southeast Asia, in the Caribbean, Middle East, North America, Europe, Oceania, Africa, and other regions.

baseline: According to Gavin Flood, "The actual term Hindu first occurs as a Persian geographical term for the people who lived beyond the river Indus (Sanskrit: Sindhu)", more specifically in the 6th-century BCE inscription of Darius I (550–486 BCE).

prompts: The term Hindu in these ancient records is a geographical term
baseline: The term Hindu in these ancient records is a geographical term and did not refer to a religion.

baseline: The word Hindu is found as heptahindu in Avesta – equivalent to Rigvedic sapta sindhu, while hndstn (pronounced Hindustan) is found in a Sasanian inscription from the 3rd century CE, both of which refer to parts of northwestern South Asia.

prompts: Among the earliest known records of ' Hindu ' with connotations of religion may be in the 7th
baseline: Among the earliest known records of 'Hindu' with connotations of religion may be in the 7th-century CE Chinese text Record of the Western Regions by Xuanzang, and 14th-century Persian text Futuhu's-salatin by 'Abd al-Malik Isami.

baseline: Some 16–18th century Bengali Gaudiya Vaishnava texts mention Hindu and Hindu dharma to distinguish from Muslims without positively defining these terms.

baseline: According to Mahatma Gandhi, "a man may not believe in God and still call himself a Hindu".

baseline: The six āstika schools of Hindu philosophy, which recognise the authority of the Vedas are: Sānkhya, Yoga, Nyāya, Vaisheshika, Mimāmsā, and Vedānta.

prompts: The major kinds , according to McDaniel are Folk Hinduism ,
baseline: The major kinds, according to McDaniel are Folk Hinduism, based on local traditions and cults of local deities and is the oldest, non-literate system; Vedic Hinduism based on the earliest layers of the Vedas, traceable to the 2nd millennium BCE; Vedantic Hinduism based on the philosophy of the Upanishads, including Advaita Vedanta, emphasising knowledge and wisdom; Yogic Hinduism, following the text of Yoga Sutras of Patanjali emphasising introspective awareness; Dharmic Hinduism or "daily morality", which McDaniel states is stereotyped in some books as the "only form of Hindu religion with a belief in karma, cows and caste"; and bhakti or devotional Hinduism, where intense emotions are elaborately incorporated in the pursuit of the spiritual.

prompts: Michaels distinguishes three Hindu religions
baseline: Michaels distinguishes three Hindu religions and four forms of Hindu religiosity.

prompts: The four forms of Hindu religiosity are the classical "
baseline: The four forms of Hindu religiosity are the classical "karma-marga", jnana-marga, bhakti-marga, and "heroism", which is rooted in militaristic traditions.

prompts: According to Michaels , one out of nine Hindu belongs by birth to
baseline: According to Michaels, one out of nine Hindu belongs by birth to one or both of the Brahmanic-Sanskritic Hinduism and Folk religion typology, whether practising or non-practicing.

baseline: Srirangam Ranganathaswamy Temple dedicated to the Hindu deity Vishnu is said to be worshiped by Ikshvaku (and the descendants of Ikshvaku Vamsam).

prompts: All aspects of a Hindu life , namely acquiring wealth ( artha
baseline: All aspects of a Hindu life, namely acquiring wealth (artha), fulfilment of desires (kama), and attaining liberation (moksha), are viewed here as part of "dharma", which encapsulates the "right way of living" and eternal harmonious principles in their fulfilment.

prompts: The use of the term Sanātana Dharma for Hinduism is a modern usage
baseline: The use of the term Sanātana Dharma for Hinduism is a modern usage, based on the belief that the origins of Hinduism lie beyond human history, as revealed in the Hindu texts.

prompts: These duties applied regardless of a Hindu 's class , caste , or sect , and they
baseline: These duties applied regardless of a Hindu's class, caste, or sect, and they contrasted with svadharma, one's "own duty", in accordance with one's class or caste (varṇa) and stage in life (puruṣārtha).

baseline: In recent years, the term has been used by Hindu leaders, reformers, and nationalists to refer to Hinduism.

baseline: Whatever the case, many Hindu religious sources see persons or groups which they consider as non-Vedic (and which reject Vedic varṇāśrama – 'caste and life stage' orthodoxy) as being heretics (pāṣaṇḍa/pākhaṇḍa).

prompts: Some in the Mimamsa school of Hindu philosophy considered the Agamas such
baseline: Some in the Mimamsa school of Hindu philosophy considered the Agamas such as the Pancaratrika to be invalid because it did not conform to the Vedas.

baseline: Though many religious Hindus implicitly acknowledge the authority of the Vedas, this acknowledgment is often "no more than a declaration that someone considers himself  a Hindu," and "most Indians today pay lip service to the Veda and have no regard for the contents of the text." Some Hindus challenge the authority of the Vedas, thereby implicitly acknowledging its importance to the history of Hinduism, states Lipner.

prompts: It was quoted by the Indian

baseline: Hindu beliefs are vast and diverse, and thus Hinduism is often referred to as a family of religions rather than a single religion.

baseline: Unlike other religions in the World, the Hindu religion does not claim any one Prophet, it does not worship any one God, it does not believe in any one philosophic concept, it does not follow any one act of religious rites or performances; in fact, it does not satisfy the traditional features of a religion or creed.
